Parsing [sent. 248 len. 31]: CHAPTER IV Student Life -LSB- The Laborious Beer King -RSB- The summer semester was in full tide ; consequently the most frequent figure in and about Heidelberg was the student .
Parsing [sent. 249 len. 20]: Most of the students were Germans , of course , but the representatives of foreign lands were very numerous .
Parsing [sent. 250 len. 23]: They hailed from every corner of the globe -- for instruction is cheap in Heidelberg , and so is living , too .
Parsing [sent. 251 len. 26]: The Anglo-American Club , composed of British and American students , had twenty-five members , and there was still much material left to draw from .
Parsing [sent. 252 len. 30]: Nine-tenths of the Heidelberg students wore no badge or uniform ; the other tenth wore caps of various colors , and belonged to social organizations called `` corps . ''
Parsing [sent. 253 len. 30]: There were five corps , each with a color of its own ; there were white caps , blue caps , and red , yellow , and green ones .
Parsing [sent. 254 len. 12]: The famous duel-fighting is confined to the `` corps '' boys .
Parsing [sent. 255 len. 14]: The `` KNEIP '' seems to be a specialty of theirs , too .
Parsing [sent. 256 len. 24]: Kneips are held , now and then , to celebrate great occasions , like the election of a beer king , for instance .
Parsing [sent. 257 len. 54]: The solemnity is simple ; the five corps assemble at night , and at a signal they all fall loading themselves with beer , out of pint-mugs , as fast as possible , and each man keeps his own count -- usually by laying aside a lucifer match for each mug he empties .
Parsing [sent. 258 len. 6]: The election is soon decided .
Parsing [sent. 259 len. 27]: When the candidates can hold no more , a count is instituted and the one who has drank the greatest number of pints is proclaimed king .
Parsing [sent. 260 len. 25]: I was told that the last beer king elected by the corps -- or by his own capabilities -- emptied his mug seventy-five times .
Parsing [sent. 261 len. 35]: No stomach could hold all that quantity at one time , of course -- but there are ways of frequently creating a vacuum , which those who have been much at sea will understand .
Parsing [sent. 262 len. 23]: One sees so many students abroad at all hours , that he presently begins to wonder if they ever have any working-hours .
Parsing [sent. 263 len. 11]: Some of them have , some of them have n't .
Parsing [sent. 264 len. 29]: Each can choose for himself whether he will work or play ; for German university life is a very free life ; it seems to have no restraints .
Parsing [sent. 265 len. 33]: The student does not live in the college buildings , but hires his own lodgings , in any locality he prefers , and he takes his meals when and where he pleases .
Parsing [sent. 266 len. 21]: He goes to bed when it suits him , and does not get up at all unless he wants to .
Parsing [sent. 267 len. 22]: He is not entered at the university for any particular length of time ; so he is likely to change about .
Parsing [sent. 268 len. 8]: He passes no examinations upon entering college .
Parsing [sent. 269 len. 32]: He merely pays a trifling fee of five or ten dollars , receives a card entitling him to the privileges of the university , and that is the end of it .
Parsing [sent. 270 len. 15]: He is now ready for business -- or play , as he shall prefer .
Parsing [sent. 271 len. 17]: If he elects to work , he finds a large list of lectures to choose from .
Parsing [sent. 272 len. 23]: He selects the subjects which he will study , and enters his name for these studies ; but he can skip attendance .
Parsing [sent. 273 len. 40]: The result of this system is , that lecture-courses upon specialties of an unusual nature are often delivered to very slim audiences , while those upon more practical and every-day matters of education are delivered to very large ones .
Parsing [sent. 274 len. 26]: I heard of one case where , day after day , the lecturer 's audience consisted of three students -- and always the same three .
Parsing [sent. 275 len. 9]: But one day two of them remained away .
Parsing [sent. 276 len. 35]: The lecturer began as usual -- `` Gentlemen , '' -- then , without a smile , he corrected himself , saying -- `` Sir , '' -- and went on with his discourse .
Parsing [sent. 277 len. 42]: It is said that the vast majority of the Heidelberg students are hard workers , and make the most of their opportunities ; that they have no surplus means to spend in dissipation , and no time to spare for frolicking .
Parsing [sent. 278 len. 40]: One lecture follows right on the heels of another , with very little time for the student to get out of one hall and into the next ; but the industrious ones manage it by going on a trot .
Parsing [sent. 279 len. 33]: The professors assist them in the saving of their time by being promptly in their little boxed-up pulpits when the hours strike , and as promptly out again when the hour finishes .
Parsing [sent. 280 len. 13]: I entered an empty lecture-room one day just before the clock struck .
Parsing [sent. 281 len. 16]: The place had simple , unpainted pine desks and benches for about two hundred persons .
Parsing [sent. 282 len. 33]: About a minute before the clock struck , a hundred and fifty students swarmed in , rushed to their seats , immediately spread open their notebooks and dipped their pens in ink .
Parsing [sent. 283 len. 71]: When the clock began to strike , a burly professor entered , was received with a round of applause , moved swiftly down the center aisle , said `` Gentlemen , '' and began to talk as he climbed his pulpit steps ; and by the time he had arrived in his box and faced his audience , his lecture was well under way and all the pens were going .
Parsing [sent. 284 len. 76]: He had no notes , he talked with prodigious rapidity and energy for an hour -- then the students began to remind him in certain well-understood ways that his time was up ; he seized his hat , still talking , proceeded swiftly down his pulpit steps , got out the last word of his discourse as he struck the floor ; everybody rose respectfully , and he swept rapidly down the aisle and disappeared .
Parsing [sent. 285 len. 23]: An instant rush for some other lecture-room followed , and in a minute I was alone with the empty benches once more .
Parsing [sent. 286 len. 12]: Yes , without doubt , idle students are not the rule .
Parsing [sent. 287 len. 26]: Out of eight hundred in the town , I knew the faces of only about fifty ; but these I saw everywhere , and daily .
Parsing [sent. 288 len. 34]: They walked about the streets and the wooded hills , they drove in cabs , they boated on the river , they sipped beer and coffee , afternoons , in the Schloss gardens .
Parsing [sent. 289 len. 12]: A good many of them wore colored caps of the corps .
Parsing [sent. 290 len. 24]: They were finely and fashionably dressed , their manners were quite superb , and they led an easy , careless , comfortable life .
Parsing [sent. 291 len. 34]: If a dozen of them sat together and a lady or a gentleman passed whom one of them knew and saluted , they all rose to their feet and took off their caps .
Parsing [sent. 292 len. 34]: The members of a corps always received a fellow-member in this way , too ; but they paid no attention to members of other corps ; they did not seem to see them .
Parsing [sent. 293 len. 19]: This was not a discourtesy ; it was only a part of the elaborate and rigid corps etiquette .
Parsing [sent. 294 len. 33]: There seems to be no chilly distance existing between the German students and the professor ; but , on the contrary , a companionable intercourse , the opposite of chilliness and reserve .
Parsing [sent. 295 len. 36]: When the professor enters a beer-hall in the evening where students are gathered together , these rise up and take off their caps , and invite the old gentleman to sit with them and partake .
Parsing [sent. 296 len. 64]: He accepts , and the pleasant talk and the beer flow for an hour or two , and by and by the professor , properly charged and comfortable , gives a cordial good night , while the students stand bowing and uncovered ; and then he moves on his happy way homeward with all his vast cargo of learning afloat in his hold .
Parsing [sent. 297 len. 13]: Nobody finds fault or feels outraged ; no harm has been done .
Parsing [sent. 298 len. 18]: It seemed to be a part of corps etiquette to keep a dog or so , too .
Parsing [sent. 299 len. 31]: I mean a corps dog -- the common property of the organization , like the corps steward or head servant ; then there are other dogs , owned by individuals .

Parsing [sent. 309 len. 17]: It would be a mistake to suppose that the easy-going pleasure-seeking student carries an empty head .
Parsing [sent. 310 len. 4]: Just the contrary .
Parsing [sent. 311 len. 28]: He has spent nine years in the gymnasium , under a system which allowed him no freedom , but vigorously compelled him to work like a slave .
Parsing [sent. 312 len. 35]: Consequently , he has left the gymnasium with an education which is so extensive and complete , that the most a university can do for it is to perfect some of its profounder specialties .
Parsing [sent. 313 len. 44]: It is said that when a pupil leaves the gymnasium , he not only has a comprehensive education , but he KNOWS what he knows -- it is not befogged with uncertainty , it is burnt into him so that it will stay .
Parsing [sent. 314 len. 22]: For instance , he does not merely read and write Greek , but speaks it ; the same with the Latin .
Parsing [sent. 315 len. 14]: Foreign youth steer clear of the gymnasium ; its rules are too severe .
Parsing [sent. 316 len. 64]: They go to the university to put a mansard roof on their whole general education ; but the German student already has his mansard roof , so he goes there to add a steeple in the nature of some specialty , such as a particular branch of law , or diseases of the eye , or special study of the ancient Gothic tongues .
Parsing [sent. 317 len. 35]: So this German attends only the lectures which belong to the chosen branch , and drinks his beer and tows his dog around and has a general good time the rest of the day .
Parsing [sent. 318 len. 76]: He has been in rigid bondage so long that the large liberty of the university life is just what he needs and likes and thoroughly appreciates ; and as it can not last forever , he makes the most of it while it does last , and so lays up a good rest against the day that must see him put on the chains once more and enter the slavery of official or professional life .

Parsing [sent. 344 len. 32]: These weird apparitions had been handsome youths , clad in fashionable attire , fifteen minutes before , but now they did not resemble any beings one ever sees unless in nightmares .
Parsing [sent. 345 len. 33]: They strode along , with their arms projecting straight out from their bodies ; they did not hold them out themselves , but fellow-students walked beside them and gave the needed support .
Parsing [sent. 346 len. 22]: There was a rush for the vacant end of the room , now , and we followed and got good places .
Parsing [sent. 347 len. 99]: The combatants were placed face to face , each with several members of his own corps about him to assist ; two seconds , well padded , and with swords in their hands , took their stations ; a student belonging to neither of the opposing corps placed himself in a good position to umpire the combat ; another student stood by with a watch and a memorandum-book to keep record of the time and the number and nature of the wounds ; a gray-haired surgeon was present with his lint , his bandages , and his instruments .
Parsing [sent. 348 len. 37]: After a moment 's pause the duelists saluted the umpire respectfully , then one after another the several officials stepped forward , gracefully removed their caps and saluted him also , and returned to their places .
Parsing [sent. 349 len. 23]: Everything was ready now ; students stood crowded together in the foreground , and others stood behind them on chairs and tables .

Parsing [sent. 351 len. 19]: The combatants were watching each other with alert eyes ; a perfect stillness , a breathless interest reigned .
Parsing [sent. 352 len. 12]: I felt that I was going to see some wary work .
Parsing [sent. 353 len. 4]: But not so .
Parsing [sent. 354 len. 87]: The instant the word was given , the two apparitions sprang forward and began to rain blows down upon each other with such lightning rapidity that I could not quite tell whether I saw the swords or only flashes they made in the air ; the rattling din of these blows as they struck steel or paddings was something wonderfully stirring , and they were struck with such terrific force that I could not understand why the opposing sword was not beaten down under the assault .
Parsing [sent. 355 len. 41]: Presently , in the midst of the sword-flashes , I saw a handful of hair skip into the air as if it had lain loose on the victim 's head and a breath of wind had puffed it suddenly away .
Parsing [sent. 356 len. 7]: The seconds cried `` Halt ! ''
Parsing [sent. 357 len. 11]: and knocked up the combatants ' swords with their own .
Parsing [sent. 358 len. 80]: The duelists sat down ; a student official stepped forward , examined the wounded head and touched the place with a sponge once or twice ; the surgeon came and turned back the hair from the wound -- and revealed a crimson gash two or three inches long , and proceeded to bind an oval piece of leather and a bunch of lint over it ; the tally-keeper stepped up and tallied one for the opposition in his book .
Parsing [sent. 359 len. 45]: Then the duelists took position again ; a small stream of blood was flowing down the side of the injured man 's head , and over his shoulder and down his body to the floor , but he did not seem to mind this .
Parsing [sent. 360 len. 47]: The word was given , and they plunged at each other as fiercely as before ; once more the blows rained and rattled and flashed ; every few moments the quick-eyed seconds would notice that a sword was bent -- then they called `` Halt ! ''
Parsing [sent. 361 len. 15]: struck up the contending weapons , and an assisting student straightened the bent one .
Parsing [sent. 362 len. 33]: The wonderful turmoil went on -- presently a bright spark sprung from a blade , and that blade broken in several pieces , sent one of its fragments flying to the ceiling .
Parsing [sent. 363 len. 10]: A new sword was provided and the fight proceeded .
Parsing [sent. 364 len. 19]: The exercise was tremendous , of course , and in time the fighters began to show great fatigue .
Parsing [sent. 365 len. 36]: They were allowed to rest a moment , every little while ; they got other rests by wounding each other , for then they could sit down while the doctor applied the lint and bandages .
Parsing [sent. 366 len. 38]: The law is that the battle must continue fifteen minutes if the men can hold out ; and as the pauses do not count , this duel was protracted to twenty or thirty minutes , I judged .
Parsing [sent. 367 len. 17]: At last it was decided that the men were too much wearied to do battle longer .

Parsing [sent. 369 len. 39]: That was a good fight , but it could not count , partly because it did not last the lawful fifteen minutes -LRB- of actual fighting -RRB- , and partly because neither man was disabled by his wound .
Parsing [sent. 370 len. 27]: It was a drawn battle , and corps law requires that drawn battles shall be refought as soon as the adversaries are well of their hurts .
Parsing [sent. 371 len. 65]: During the conflict , I had talked a little , now and then , with a young gentleman of the White Cap Corps , and he had mentioned that he was to fight next -- and had also pointed out his challenger , a young gentleman who was leaning against the opposite wall smoking a cigarette and restfully observing the duel then in progress .
Parsing [sent. 372 len. 63]: My acquaintanceship with a party to the coming contest had the effect of giving me a kind of personal interest in it ; I naturally wished he might win , and it was the reverse of pleasant to learn that he probably would not , because , although he was a notable swordsman , the challenger was held to be his superior .

Parsing [sent. 374 len. 27]: I stood close by , but could not tell which blows told and which did not , they fell and vanished so like flashes of light .
Parsing [sent. 375 len. 52]: They all seemed to tell ; the swords always bent over the opponents ' heads , from the forehead back over the crown , and seemed to touch , all the way ; but it was not so -- a protecting blade , invisible to me , was always interposed between .
Parsing [sent. 376 len. 45]: At the end of ten seconds each man had struck twelve or fifteen blows , and warded off twelve or fifteen , and no harm done ; then a sword became disabled , and a short rest followed whilst a new one was brought .
Parsing [sent. 377 len. 27]: Early in the next round the White Corps student got an ugly wound on the side of his head and gave his opponent one like it .
Parsing [sent. 378 len. 22]: In the third round the latter received another bad wound in the head , and the former had his under-lip divided .
Parsing [sent. 379 len. 21]: After that , the White Corps student gave many severe wounds , but got none of the consequence in return .
Parsing [sent. 380 len. 33]: At the end of five minutes from the beginning of the duel the surgeon stopped it ; the challenging party had suffered such injuries that any addition to them might be dangerous .
Parsing [sent. 381 len. 13]: These injuries were a fearful spectacle , but are better left undescribed .
Parsing [sent. 382 len. 11]: So , against expectation , my acquaintance was the victor .
Parsing [sent. 383 len. 17]: CHAPTER VI -LSB- A Sport that Sometimes Kills -RSB- The third duel was brief and bloody .
Parsing [sent. 384 len. 28]: The surgeon stopped it when he saw that one of the men had received such bad wounds that he could not fight longer without endangering his life .
Parsing [sent. 385 len. 39]: The fourth duel was a tremendous encounter ; but at the end of five or six minutes the surgeon interfered once more : another man so severely hurt as to render it unsafe to add to his harms .
Parsing [sent. 386 len. 57]: I watched this engagement as I watched the others -- with rapt interest and strong excitement , and with a shrink and a shudder for every blow that laid open a cheek or a forehead ; and a conscious paling of my face when I occasionally saw a wound of a yet more shocking nature inflicted .
Parsing [sent. 387 len. 40]: My eyes were upon the loser of this duel when he got his last and vanquishing wound -- it was in his face and it carried away his -- but no matter , I must not enter into details .
Parsing [sent. 388 len. 28]: I had but a glance , and then turned quickly , but I would not have been looking at all if I had known what was coming .
Parsing [sent. 389 len. 59]: No , that is probably not true ; one thinks he would not look if he knew what was coming , but the interest and the excitement are so powerful that they would doubtless conquer all other feelings ; and so , under the fierce exhilaration of the clashing steel , he would yield and look after all .
Parsing [sent. 390 len. 20]: Sometimes spectators of these duels faint -- and it does seem a very reasonable thing to do , too .
Parsing [sent. 391 len. 31]: Both parties to this fourth duel were badly hurt so much that the surgeon was at work upon them nearly or quite an hour -- a fact which is suggestive .
Parsing [sent. 392 len. 14]: But this waiting interval was not wasted in idleness by the assembled students .
Parsing [sent. 393 len. 45]: It was past noon , therefore they ordered their landlord , downstairs , to send up hot beefsteaks , chickens , and such things , and these they ate , sitting comfortable at the several tables , whilst they chatted , disputed and laughed .
Parsing [sent. 394 len. 38]: The door to the surgeon 's room stood open , meantime , but the cutting , sewing , splicing , and bandaging going on in there in plain view did not seem to disturb anyone 's appetite .
Parsing [sent. 395 len. 69]: I went in and saw the surgeon labor awhile , but could not enjoy ; it was much less trying to see the wounds given and received than to see them mended ; the stir and turmoil , and the music of the steel , were wanting here -- one 's nerves were wrung by this grisly spectacle , whilst the duel 's compensating pleasurable thrill was lacking .
Parsing [sent. 396 len. 21]: Finally the doctor finished , and the men who were to fight the closing battle of the day came forth .
Parsing [sent. 397 len. 31]: A good many dinners were not completed , yet , but no matter , they could be eaten cold , after the battle ; therefore everybody crowded forth to see .
Parsing [sent. 398 len. 14]: This was not a love duel , but a `` satisfaction '' affair .
Parsing [sent. 399 len. 13]: These two students had quarreled , and were here to settle it .
Parsing [sent. 400 len. 32]: They did not belong to any of the corps , but they were furnished with weapons and armor , and permitted to fight here by the five corps as a courtesy .
Parsing [sent. 401 len. 21]: Evidently these two young men were unfamiliar with the dueling ceremonies , though they were not unfamiliar with the sword .
Parsing [sent. 402 len. 37]: When they were placed in position they thought it was time to begin -- and then did begin , too , and with a most impetuous energy , without waiting for anybody to give the word .
Parsing [sent. 403 len. 21]: This vastly amused the spectators , and even broke down their studied and courtly gravity and surprised them into laughter .
Parsing [sent. 404 len. 15]: Of course the seconds struck up the swords and started the duel over again .
Parsing [sent. 405 len. 38]: At the word , the deluge of blows began , but before long the surgeon once more interfered -- for the only reason which ever permits him to interfere -- and the day 's war was over .
Parsing [sent. 406 len. 21]: It was now two in the afternoon , and I had been present since half past nine in the morning .
Parsing [sent. 407 len. 20]: The field of battle was indeed a red one by this time ; but some sawdust soon righted that .
Parsing [sent. 408 len. 9]: There had been one duel before I arrived .
Parsing [sent. 409 len. 19]: In it one of the men received many injuries , while the other one escaped without a scratch .
Parsing [sent. 410 len. 49]: I had seen the heads and faces of ten youths gashed in every direction by the keen two-edged blades , and yet had not seen a victim wince , nor heard a moan , or detected any fleeting expression which confessed the sharp pain the hurts were inflicting .
Parsing [sent. 411 len. 7]: This was good fortitude , indeed .
Parsing [sent. 412 len. 41]: Such endurance is to be expected in savages and prize-fighters , for they are born and educated to it ; but to find it in such perfection in these gently bred and kindly natured young fellows is matter for surprise .
Parsing [sent. 413 len. 37]: It was not merely under the excitement of the sword-play that this fortitude was shown ; it was shown in the surgeon 's room where an uninspiring quiet reigned , and where there was no audience .
Parsing [sent. 414 len. 11]: The doctor 's manipulations brought out neither grimaces nor moans .
Parsing [sent. 415 len. 35]: And in the fights it was observable that these lads hacked and slashed with the same tremendous spirit , after they were covered with streaming wounds , which they had shown in the beginning .
Parsing [sent. 416 len. 61]: The world in general looks upon the college duels as very farcical affairs : true , but considering that the college duel is fought by boys ; that the swords are real swords ; and that the head and face are exposed , it seems to me that it is a farce which had quite a grave side to it .
Parsing [sent. 417 len. 23]: People laugh at it mainly because they think the student is so covered up with armor that he can not be hurt .
Parsing [sent. 418 len. 24]: But it is not so ; his eyes and ears are protected , but the rest of his face and head are bare .
Parsing [sent. 419 len. 29]: He can not only be badly wounded , but his life is in danger ; and he would sometimes lose it but for the interference of the surgeon .
Parsing [sent. 420 len. 11]: It is not intended that his life shall be endangered .
Parsing [sent. 421 len. 7]: Fatal accidents are possible , however .
Parsing [sent. 422 len. 37]: For instance , the student 's sword may break , and the end of it fly up behind his antagonist 's ear and cut an artery which could not be reached if the sword remained whole .
Parsing [sent. 423 len. 14]: This has happened , sometimes , and death has resulted on the spot .
Parsing [sent. 424 len. 39]: Formerly the student 's armpits were not protected -- and at that time the swords were pointed , whereas they are blunt , now ; so an artery in the armpit was sometimes cut , and death followed .
Parsing [sent. 425 len. 41]: Then in the days of sharp-pointed swords , a spectator was an occasional victim -- the end of a broken sword flew five or ten feet and buried itself in his neck or his heart , and death ensued instantly .
Parsing [sent. 426 len. 57]: The student duels in Germany occasion two or three deaths every year , now , but this arises only from the carelessness of the wounded men ; they eat or drink imprudently , or commit excesses in the way of overexertion ; inflammation sets in and gets such a headway that it can not be arrested .
Parsing [sent. 427 len. 24]: Indeed , there is blood and pain and danger enough about the college duel to entitle it to a considerable degree of respect .
Parsing [sent. 428 len. 22]: All the customs , all the laws , all the details , pertaining to the student duel are quaint and naive .
Parsing [sent. 429 len. 24]: The grave , precise , and courtly ceremony with which the thing is conducted , invests it with a sort of antique charm .
Parsing [sent. 430 len. 14]: This dignity and these knightly graces suggest the tournament , not the prize-fight .
Parsing [sent. 431 len. 10]: The laws are as curious as they are strict .
Parsing [sent. 432 len. 26]: For instance , the duelist may step forward from the line he is placed upon , if he chooses , but never back of it .
Parsing [sent. 433 len. 38]: If he steps back of it , or even leans back , it is considered that he did it to avoid a blow or contrive an advantage ; so he is dismissed from his corps in disgrace .
Parsing [sent. 434 len. 28]: It would seem natural to step from under a descending sword unconsciously , and against one 's will and intent -- yet this unconsciousness is not allowed .
Parsing [sent. 435 len. 52]: Again : if under the sudden anguish of a wound the receiver of it makes a grimace , he falls some degrees in the estimation of his fellows ; his corps are ashamed of him : they call him `` hare foot , '' which is the German equivalent for chicken-hearted .
Parsing [sent. 436 len. 26]: CHAPTER VII -LSB- How Bismark Fought -RSB- In addition to the corps laws , there are some corps usages which have the force of laws .
Parsing [sent. 437 len. 77]: Perhaps the president of a corps notices that one of the membership who is no longer an exempt -- that is a freshman -- has remained a sophomore some little time without volunteering to fight ; some day , the president , instead of calling for volunteers , will APPOINT this sophomore to measure swords with a student of another corps ; he is free to decline -- everybody says so -- there is no compulsion .
Parsing [sent. 438 len. 57]: This is all true -- but I have not heard of any student who DID decline ; to decline and still remain in the corps would make him unpleasantly conspicuous , and properly so , since he knew , when he joined , that his main business , as a member , would be to fight .
Parsing [sent. 439 len. 25]: No , there is no law against declining -- except the law of custom , which is confessedly stronger than written law , everywhere .
Parsing [sent. 440 len. 52]: The ten men whose duels I had witnessed did not go away when their hurts were dressed , as I had supposed they would , but came back , one after another , as soon as they were free of the surgeon , and mingled with the assemblage in the dueling-room .
Parsing [sent. 441 len. 21]: The white-cap student who won the second fight witnessed the remaining three , and talked with us during the intermissions .
Parsing [sent. 442 len. 61]: He could not talk very well , because his opponent 's sword had cut his under-lip in two , and then the surgeon had sewed it together and overlaid it with a profusion of white plaster patches ; neither could he eat easily , still he contrived to accomplish a slow and troublesome luncheon while the last duel was preparing .
Parsing [sent. 443 len. 18]: The man who was the worst hurt of all played chess while waiting to see this engagement .
Parsing [sent. 444 len. 27]: A good part of his face was covered with patches and bandages , and all the rest of his head was covered and concealed by them .
Parsing [sent. 445 len. 44]: It is said that the student likes to appear on the street and in other public places in this kind of array , and that this predilection often keeps him out when exposure to rain or sun is a positive danger for him .
Parsing [sent. 446 len. 15]: Newly bandaged students are a very common spectacle in the public gardens of Heidelberg .
Parsing [sent. 447 len. 73]: It is also said that the student is glad to get wounds in the face , because the scars they leave will show so well there ; and it is also said that these face wounds are so prized that youths have even been known to pull them apart from time to time and put red wine in them to make them heal badly and leave as ugly a scar as possible .
Parsing [sent. 448 len. 44]: It does not look reasonable , but it is roundly asserted and maintained , nevertheless ; I am sure of one thing -- scars are plenty enough in Germany , among the young men ; and very grim ones they are , too .
Parsing [sent. 449 len. 15]: They crisscross the face in angry red welts , and are permanent and ineffaceable .
Parsing [sent. 450 len. 46]: Some of these scars are of a very strange and dreadful aspect ; and the effect is striking when several such accent the milder ones , which form a city map on a man 's face ; they suggest the `` burned district '' then .
Parsing [sent. 451 len. 21]: We had often noticed that many of the students wore a colored silk band or ribbon diagonally across their breasts .
Parsing [sent. 452 len. 36]: It transpired that this signifies that the wearer has fought three duels in which a decision was reached -- duels in which he either whipped or was whipped -- for drawn battles do not count .
Parsing [sent. 453 len. 59]: -LSB- 1 -RSB- After a student has received his ribbon , he is `` free '' ; he can cease from fighting , without reproach -- except some one insult him ; his president can not appoint him to fight ; he can volunteer if he wants to , or remain quiescent if he prefers to do so .
Parsing [sent. 454 len. 11]: Statistics show that he does NOT prefer to remain quiescent .
Parsing [sent. 455 len. 33]: They show that the duel has a singular fascination about it somewhere , for these free men , so far from resting upon the privilege of the badge , are always volunteering .
Parsing [sent. 456 len. 28]: A corps student told me it was of record that Prince Bismarck fought thirty-two of these duels in a single summer term when he was in college .
Parsing [sent. 457 len. 18]: So he fought twenty-nine after his badge had given him the right to retire from the field .

Parsing [sent. 459 len. 4]: FROM MY DIARY .
Parsing [sent. 460 len. 55]: -- Dined in a hotel a few miles up the Neckar , in a room whose walls were hung all over with framed portrait-groups of the Five Corps ; some were recent , but many antedated photography , and were pictured in lithography -- the dates ranged back to forty or fifty years ago .
Parsing [sent. 461 len. 10]: Nearly every individual wore the ribbon across his breast .
Parsing [sent. 462 len. 38]: In one portrait-group representing -LRB- as each of these pictures did -RRB- an entire Corps , I took pains to count the ribbons : there were twenty-seven members , and twenty-one of them wore that significant badge .
Parsing [sent. 463 len. 12]: The statistics may be found to possess interest in several particulars .
Parsing [sent. 464 len. 10]: Two days in every week are devoted to dueling .
Parsing [sent. 465 len. 28]: The rule is rigid that there must be three duels on each of these days ; there are generally more , but there can not be fewer .
Parsing [sent. 466 len. 16]: There were six the day I was present ; sometimes there are seven or eight .
Parsing [sent. 467 len. 46]: It is insisted that eight duels a week -- four for each of the two days -- is too low an average to draw a calculation from , but I will reckon from that basis , preferring an understatement to an overstatement of the case .
Parsing [sent. 468 len. 39]: This requires about four hundred and eighty or five hundred duelists a year -- for in summer the college term is about three and a half months , and in winter it is four months and sometimes longer .
Parsing [sent. 469 len. 64]: Of the seven hundred and fifty students in the university at the time I am writing of , only eighty belonged to the five corps , and it is only these corps that do the dueling ; occasionally other students borrow the arms and battleground of the five corps in order to settle a quarrel , but this does not happen every dueling-day .
Parsing [sent. 470 len. 19]: -LSB- 2 -RSB- Consequently eighty youths furnish the material for some two hundred and fifty duels a year .
Parsing [sent. 471 len. 13]: This average gives six fights a year to each of the eighty .
Parsing [sent. 472 len. 19]: This large work could not be accomplished if the badge-holders stood upon their privilege and ceased to volunteer .
Parsing [sent. 473 len. 2]: 2 .
Parsing [sent. 474 len. 16]: They have to borrow the arms because they could not get them elsewhere or otherwise .
Parsing [sent. 475 len. 30]: As I understand it , the public authorities , all over Germany , allow the five Corps to keep swords , but DO NOT ALLOW THEM TO USE THEM .
Parsing [sent. 476 len. 17]: This is law is rigid ; it is only the execution of it that is lax .
Parsing [sent. 477 len. 26]: Of course , where there is so much fighting , the students make it a point to keep themselves in constant practice with the foil .
Parsing [sent. 478 len. 91]: One often sees them , at the tables in the Castle grounds , using their whips or canes to illustrate some new sword trick which they have heard about ; and between the duels , on the day whose history I have been writing , the swords were not always idle ; every now and then we heard a succession of the keen hissing sounds which the sword makes when it is being put through its paces in the air , and this informed us that a student was practicing .
Parsing [sent. 479 len. 13]: Necessarily , this unceasing attention to the art develops an expert occasionally .
Parsing [sent. 480 len. 15]: He becomes famous in his own university , his renown spreads to other universities .
Parsing [sent. 481 len. 36]: He is invited to Goettingen , to fight with a Goettingen expert ; if he is victorious , he will be invited to other colleges , or those colleges will send their experts to him .
Parsing [sent. 482 len. 13]: Americans and Englishmen often join one or another of the five corps .
Parsing [sent. 483 len. 45]: A year or two ago , the principal Heidelberg expert was a big Kentuckian ; he was invited to the various universities and left a wake of victory behind him all about Germany ; but at last a little student in Strasburg defeated him .
Parsing [sent. 484 len. 28]: There was formerly a student in Heidelberg who had picked up somewhere and mastered a peculiar trick of cutting up under instead of cleaving down from above .
Parsing [sent. 485 len. 37]: While the trick lasted he won in sixteen successive duels in his university ; but by that time observers had discovered what his charm was , and how to break it , therefore his championship ceased .
Parsing [sent. 486 len. 14]: A rule which forbids social intercourse between members of different corps is strict .
Parsing [sent. 487 len. 29]: In the dueling-house , in the parks , on the street , and anywhere and everywhere that the students go , caps of a color group themselves together .
Parsing [sent. 488 len. 72]: If all the tables in a public garden were crowded but one , and that one had two red-cap students at it and ten vacant places , the yellow-caps , the blue-caps , the white caps , and the green caps , seeking seats , would go by that table and not seem to see it , nor seem to be aware that there was such a table in the grounds .
Parsing [sent. 489 len. 22]: The student by whose courtesy we had been enabled to visit the dueling-place , wore the white cap -- Prussian Corps .
Parsing [sent. 490 len. 15]: He introduced us to many white caps , but to none of another color .
Parsing [sent. 491 len. 48]: The corps etiquette extended even to us , who were strangers , and required us to group with the white corps only , and speak only with the white corps , while we were their guests , and keep aloof from the caps of the other colors .
Parsing [sent. 492 len. 54]: Once I wished to examine some of the swords , but an American student said , `` It would not be quite polite ; these now in the windows all have red hilts or blue ; they will bring in some with white hilts presently , and those you can handle freely . ''
Parsing [sent. 493 len. 38]: When a sword was broken in the first duel , I wanted a piece of it ; but its hilt was the wrong color , so it was considered best and politest to await a properer season .
Parsing [sent. 494 len. 41]: It was brought to me after the room was cleared , and I will now make a `` life-size '' sketch of it by tracing a line around it with my pen , to show the width of the weapon .
Parsing [sent. 495 len. 20]: -LSB- Figure 1 -RSB- The length of these swords is about three feet , and they are quite heavy .
Parsing [sent. 496 len. 31]: One 's disposition to cheer , during the course of the duels or at their close , was naturally strong , but corps etiquette forbade any demonstrations of this sort .
Parsing [sent. 497 len. 21]: However brilliant a contest or a victory might be , no sign or sound betrayed that any one was moved .
Parsing [sent. 498 len. 11]: A dignified gravity and repression were maintained at all times .
Parsing [sent. 499 len. 101]: When the dueling was finished and we were ready to go , the gentlemen of the Prussian Corps to whom we had been introduced took off their caps in the courteous German way , and also shook hands ; their brethren of the same order took off their caps and bowed , but without shaking hands ; the gentlemen of the other corps treated us just as they would have treated white caps -- they fell apart , apparently unconsciously , and left us an unobstructed pathway , but did not seem to see us or know we were there .
Parsing [sent. 500 len. 36]: If we had gone thither the following week as guests of another corps , the white caps , without meaning any offense , would have observed the etiquette of their order and ignored our presence .
Parsing [sent. 501 len. 12]: -LSB- How strangely are comedy and tragedy blended in this life !
Parsing [sent. 502 len. 53]: I had not been home a full half-hour , after witnessing those playful sham-duels , when circumstances made it necessary for me to get ready immediately to assist personally at a real one -- a duel with no effeminate limitation in the matter of results , but a battle to the death .

Parsing [sent. 551 len. 19]: Since it is always fought in the open air , the combatants are nearly sure to catch cold .
Parsing [sent. 552 len. 78]: M. Paul de Cassagnac , the most inveterate of the French duelists , had suffered so often in this way that he is at last a confirmed invalid ; and the best physician in Paris has expressed the opinion that if he goes on dueling for fifteen or twenty years more -- unless he forms the habit of fighting in a comfortable room where damps and draughts can not intrude -- he will eventually endanger his life .
Parsing [sent. 553 len. 33]: This ought to moderate the talk of those people who are so stubborn in maintaining that the French duel is the most health-giving of recreations because of the open-air exercise it affords .
Parsing [sent. 554 len. 23]: And it ought also to moderate that foolish talk about French duelists and socialist-hated monarchs being the only people who are immoral .
Parsing [sent. 555 len. 10]: But it is time to get at my subject .
Parsing [sent. 556 len. 28]: As soon as I heard of the late fiery outbreak between M. Gambetta and M. Fourtou in the French Assembly , I knew that trouble must follow .
Parsing [sent. 557 len. 23]: I knew it because a long personal friendship with M. Gambetta revealed to me the desperate and implacable nature of the man .
Parsing [sent. 558 len. 24]: Vast as are his physical proportions , I knew that the thirst for revenge would penetrate to the remotest frontiers of his person .
Parsing [sent. 559 len. 18]: I did not wait for him to call on me , but went at once to him .
Parsing [sent. 560 len. 17]: As I had expected , I found the brave fellow steeped in a profound French calm .

Parsing [sent. 1159 len. 49]: Mr. X pranced in , in his long night-garment , with a candle , young Z after him with another candle ; a procession swept in at another door , with candles and lanterns -- landlord and two German guests in their nightgowns and a chambermaid in hers .
Parsing [sent. 1160 len. 19]: I looked around ; I was at Harris 's bed , a Sabbath-day 's journey from my own .
Parsing [sent. 1161 len. 46]: There was only one sofa ; it was against the wall ; there was only one chair where a body could get at it -- I had been revolving around it like a planet , and colliding with it like a comet half the night .
Parsing [sent. 1162 len. 12]: I explained how I had been employing myself , and why .
Parsing [sent. 1163 len. 27]: Then the landlord 's party left , and the rest of us set about our preparations for breakfast , for the dawn was ready to break .
Parsing [sent. 1164 len. 15]: I glanced furtively at my pedometer , and found I had made 47 miles .
Parsing [sent. 1165 len. 17]: But I did not care , for I had come out for a pedestrian tour anyway .
Parsing [sent. 1166 len. 45]: CHAPTER XIV -LSB- Rafting Down the Neckar -RSB- When the landlord learned that I and my agents were artists , our party rose perceptibly in his esteem ; we rose still higher when he learned that we were making a pedestrian tour of Europe .
Parsing [sent. 1167 len. 101]: He told us all about the Heidelberg road , and which were the best places to avoid and which the best ones to tarry at ; he charged me less than cost for the things I broke in the night ; he put up a fine luncheon for us and added to it a quantity of great light-green plums , the pleasantest fruit in Germany ; he was so anxious to do us honor that he would not allow us to walk out of Heilbronn , but called up Goetz von Berlichingen 's horse and cab and made us ride .
Parsing [sent. 1168 len. 8]: I made a sketch of the turnout .
Parsing [sent. 1169 len. 26]: It is not a Work , it is only what artists call a `` study '' -- a thing to make a finished picture from .
Parsing [sent. 1170 len. 23]: This sketch has several blemishes in it ; for instance , the wagon is not traveling as fast as the horse is .
Parsing [sent. 1171 len. 4]: This is wrong .
Parsing [sent. 1172 len. 25]: Again , the person trying to get out of the way is too small ; he is out of perspective , as we say .
Parsing [sent. 1173 len. 36]: The two upper lines are not the horse 's back , they are the reigns ; there seems to be a wheel missing -- this would be corrected in a finished Work , of course .
Parsing [sent. 1174 len. 15]: This thing flying out behind is not a flag , it is a curtain .
Parsing [sent. 1175 len. 19]: That other thing up there is the sun , but I did n't get enough distance on it .
Parsing [sent. 1176 len. 33]: I do not remember , now , what that thing is that is in front of the man who is running , but I think it is a haystack or a woman .
Parsing [sent. 1177 len. 26]: This study was exhibited in the Paris Salon of 1879 , but did not take any medal ; they do not give medals for studies .
Parsing [sent. 1178 len. 8]: We discharged the carriage at the bridge .
Parsing [sent. 1179 len. 35]: The river was full of logs -- long , slender , barkless pine logs -- and we leaned on the rails of the bridge , and watched the men put them together into rafts .
Parsing [sent. 1180 len. 19]: These rafts were of a shape and construction to suit the crookedness and extreme narrowness of the Neckar .
Parsing [sent. 1181 len. 30]: They were from fifty to one hundred yards long , and they gradually tapered from a nine-log breadth at their sterns , to a three-log breadth at their bow-ends .
Parsing [sent. 1182 len. 43]: The main part of the steering is done at the bow , with a pole ; the three-log breadth there furnishes room for only the steersman , for these little logs are not larger around than an average young lady 's waist .
Parsing [sent. 1183 len. 35]: The connections of the several sections of the raft are slack and pliant , so that the raft may be readily bent into any sort of curve required by the shape of the river .
Parsing [sent. 1184 len. 48]: The Neckar is in many places so narrow that a person can throw a dog across it , if he has one ; when it is also sharply curved in such places , the raftsman has to do some pretty nice snug piloting to make the turns .
Parsing [sent. 1185 len. 54]: The river is not always allowed to spread over its whole bed -- which is as much as thirty , and sometimes forty yards wide -- but is split into three equal bodies of water , by stone dikes which throw the main volume , depth , and current into the central one .
Parsing [sent. 1186 len. 32]: In low water these neat narrow-edged dikes project four or five inches above the surface , like the comb of a submerged roof , but in high water they are overflowed .
Parsing [sent. 1187 len. 18]: A hatful of rain makes high water in the Neckar , and a basketful produces an overflow .
Parsing [sent. 1188 len. 18]: There are dikes abreast the Schloss Hotel , and the current is violently swift at that point .
Parsing [sent. 1189 len. 74]: I used to sit for hours in my glass cage , watching the long , narrow rafts slip along through the central channel , grazing the right-bank dike and aiming carefully for the middle arch of the stone bridge below ; I watched them in this way , and lost all this time hoping to see one of them hit the bridge-pier and wreck itself sometime or other , but was always disappointed .
Parsing [sent. 1190 len. 27]: One was smashed there one morning , but I had just stepped into my room a moment to light a pipe , so I lost it .
Parsing [sent. 1191 len. 40]: While I was looking down upon the rafts that morning in Heilbronn , the daredevil spirit of adventure came suddenly upon me , and I said to my comrades : `` I am going to Heidelberg on a raft .
Parsing [sent. 1192 len. 7]: Will you venture with me ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1193 len. 18]: Their faces paled a little , but they assented with as good a grace as they could .
Parsing [sent. 1194 len. 55]: Harris wanted to cable his mother -- thought it his duty to do that , as he was all she had in this world -- so , while he attended to this , I went down to the longest and finest raft and hailed the captain with a hearty `` Ahoy , shipmate ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1195 len. 15]: which put us upon pleasant terms at once , and we entered upon business .
Parsing [sent. 1196 len. 20]: I said we were on a pedestrian tour to Heidelberg , and would like to take passage with him .
Parsing [sent. 1197 len. 25]: I said this partly through young Z , who spoke German very well , and partly through Mr. X , who spoke it peculiarly .
Parsing [sent. 1198 len. 22]: I can UNDERSTAND German as well as the maniac that invented it , but I TALK it best through an interpreter .
Parsing [sent. 1199 len. 13]: The captain hitched up his trousers , then shifted his quid thoughtfully .
Parsing [sent. 1200 len. 43]: Presently he said just what I was expecting he would say -- that he had no license to carry passengers , and therefore was afraid the law would be after him in case the matter got noised about or any accident happened .
Parsing [sent. 1201 len. 16]: So I CHARTERED the raft and the crew and took all the responsibilities on myself .
Parsing [sent. 1202 len. 45]: With a rattling song the starboard watch bent to their work and hove the cable short , then got the anchor home , and our bark moved off with a stately stride , and soon was bowling along at about two knots an hour .
Parsing [sent. 1203 len. 6]: Our party were grouped amidships .
Parsing [sent. 1204 len. 101]: At first the talk was a little gloomy , and ran mainly upon the shortness of life , the uncertainty of it , the perils which beset it , and the need and wisdom of being always prepared for the worst ; this shaded off into low-voiced references to the dangers of the deep , and kindred matters ; but as the gray east began to redden and the mysterious solemnity and silence of the dawn to give place to the joy-songs of the birds , the talk took a cheerier tone , and our spirits began to rise steadily .
Parsing [sent. 1205 len. 43]: Germany , in the summer , is the perfection of the beautiful , but nobody has understood , and realized , and enjoyed the utmost possibilities of this soft and peaceful beauty unless he has voyaged down the Neckar on a raft .
Parsing [sent. 1206 len. 73]: The motion of a raft is the needful motion ; it is gentle , and gliding , and smooth , and noiseless ; it calms down all feverish activities , it soothes to sleep all nervous hurry and impatience ; under its restful influence all the troubles and vexations and sorrows that harass the mind vanish away , and existence becomes a dream , a charm , a deep and tranquil ecstasy .
Parsing [sent. 1207 len. 27]: How it contrasts with hot and perspiring pedestrianism , and dusty and deafening railroad rush , and tedious jolting behind tired horses over blinding white roads !
Parsing [sent. 1208 len. 30]: We went slipping silently along , between the green and fragrant banks , with a sense of pleasure and contentment that grew , and grew , all the time .
Parsing [sent. 1209 len. 89]: Sometimes the banks were overhung with thick masses of willows that wholly hid the ground behind ; sometimes we had noble hills on one hand , clothed densely with foliage to their tops , and on the other hand open levels blazing with poppies , or clothed in the rich blue of the corn-flower ; sometimes we drifted in the shadow of forests , and sometimes along the margin of long stretches of velvety grass , fresh and green and bright , a tireless charm to the eye .
Parsing [sent. 1210 len. 4]: And the birds !
Parsing [sent. 1211 len. 23]: -- they were everywhere ; they swept back and forth across the river constantly , and their jubilant music was never stilled .
Parsing [sent. 1212 len. 42]: It was a deep and satisfying pleasure to see the sun create the new morning , and gradually , patiently , lovingly , clothe it on with splendor after splendor , and glory after glory , till the miracle was complete .
Parsing [sent. 1213 len. 41]: How different is this marvel observed from a raft , from what it is when one observes it through the dingy windows of a railway-station in some wretched village while he munches a petrified sandwich and waits for the train .

Parsing [sent. 1265 len. 41]: The people often stepped aboard the raft , as we glided along the grassy shores , and gossiped with us and with the crew for a hundred yards or so , then stepped ashore again , refreshed by the ride .
Parsing [sent. 1266 len. 12]: Only the men did this ; the women were too busy .
Parsing [sent. 1267 len. 11]: The women do all kinds of work on the continent .
Parsing [sent. 1268 len. 57]: They dig , they hoe , they reap , they sow , they bear monstrous burdens on their backs , they shove similar ones long distances on wheelbarrows , they drag the cart when there is no dog or lean cow to drag it -- and when there is , they assist the dog or cow .
Parsing [sent. 1269 len. 16]: Age is no matter -- the older the woman the stronger she is , apparently .
Parsing [sent. 1270 len. 39]: On the farm a woman 's duties are not defined -- she does a little of everything ; but in the towns it is different , there she only does certain things , the men do the rest .
Parsing [sent. 1271 len. 50]: For instance , a hotel chambermaid has nothing to do but make beds and fires in fifty or sixty rooms , bring towels and candles , and fetch several tons of water up several flights of stairs , a hundred pounds at a time , in prodigious metal pitchers .
Parsing [sent. 1272 len. 41]: She does not have to work more than eighteen or twenty hours a day , and she can always get down on her knees and scrub the floors of halls and closets when she is tired and needs a rest .
Parsing [sent. 1273 len. 46]: As the morning advanced and the weather grew hot , we took off our outside clothing and sat in a row along the edge of the raft and enjoyed the scenery , with our sun-umbrellas over our heads and our legs dangling in the water .
Parsing [sent. 1274 len. 12]: Every now and then we plunged in and had a swim .
Parsing [sent. 1275 len. 43]: Every projecting grassy cape had its joyous group of naked children , the boys to themselves and the girls to themselves , the latter usually in care of some motherly dame who sat in the shade of a tree with her knitting .
Parsing [sent. 1276 len. 38]: The little boys swam out to us , sometimes , but the little maids stood knee-deep in the water and stopped their splashing and frolicking to inspect the raft with their innocent eyes as it drifted by .
Parsing [sent. 1277 len. 23]: Once we turned a corner suddenly and surprised a slender girl of twelve years or upward , just stepping into the water .
Parsing [sent. 1278 len. 43]: She had not time to run , but she did what answered just as well ; she promptly drew a lithe young willow bough athwart her white body with one hand , and then contemplated us with a simple and untroubled interest .
Parsing [sent. 1279 len. 8]: Thus she stood while we glided by .
Parsing [sent. 1280 len. 32]: She was a pretty creature , and she and her willow bough made a very pretty picture , and one which could not offend the modesty of the most fastidious spectator .
Parsing [sent. 1281 len. 41]: Her white skin had a low bank of fresh green willows for background and effective contrast -- for she stood against them -- and above and out of them projected the eager faces and white shoulders of two smaller girls .
Parsing [sent. 1282 len. 14]: Toward noon we heard the inspiriting cry , -- `` Sail ho ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1283 len. 5]: `` Where away ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1284 len. 4]: shouted the captain .
Parsing [sent. 1285 len. 9]: `` Three points off the weather bow ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1286 len. 8]: We ran forward to see the vessel .
Parsing [sent. 1287 len. 26]: It proved to be a steamboat -- for they had begun to run a steamer up the Neckar , for the first time in May .
Parsing [sent. 1288 len. 15]: She was a tug , and one of a very peculiar build and aspect .
Parsing [sent. 1289 len. 25]: I had often watched her from the hotel , and wondered how she propelled herself , for apparently she had no propeller or paddles .
Parsing [sent. 1290 len. 31]: She came churning along , now , making a deal of noise of one kind or another , and aggravating it every now and then by blowing a hoarse whistle .
Parsing [sent. 1291 len. 18]: She had nine keel-boats hitched on behind and following after her in a long , slender rank .
Parsing [sent. 1292 len. 24]: We met her in a narrow place , between dikes , and there was hardly room for us both in the cramped passage .
Parsing [sent. 1293 len. 17]: As she went grinding and groaning by , we perceived the secret of her moving impulse .
Parsing [sent. 1294 len. 23]: She did not drive herself up the river with paddles or propeller , she pulled herself by hauling on a great chain .
Parsing [sent. 1295 len. 19]: This chain is laid in the bed of the river and is only fastened at the two ends .
Parsing [sent. 1296 len. 6]: It is seventy miles long .
Parsing [sent. 1297 len. 20]: It comes in over the boat 's bow , passes around a drum , and is payed out astern .
Parsing [sent. 1298 len. 17]: She pulls on that chain , and so drags herself up the river or down it .
Parsing [sent. 1299 len. 25]: She has neither bow or stern , strictly speaking , for she has a long-bladed rudder on each end and she never turns around .
Parsing [sent. 1300 len. 39]: She uses both rudders all the time , and they are powerful enough to enable her to turn to the right or the left and steer around curves , in spite of the strong resistance of the chain .
Parsing [sent. 1301 len. 34]: I would not have believed that that impossible thing could be done ; but I saw it done , and therefore I know that there is one impossible thing which CAN be done .
Parsing [sent. 1302 len. 7]: What miracle will man attempt next ?
Parsing [sent. 1303 len. 25]: We met many big keel-boats on their way up , using sails , mule power , and profanity -- a tedious and laborious business .
Parsing [sent. 1304 len. 56]: A wire rope led from the foretopmast to the file of mules on the tow-path a hundred yards ahead , and by dint of much banging and swearing and urging , the detachment of drivers managed to get a speed of two or three miles an hour out of the mules against the stiff current .
Parsing [sent. 1305 len. 79]: The Neckar has always been used as a canal , and thus has given employment to a great many men and animals ; but now that this steamboat is able , with a small crew and a bushel or so of coal , to take nine keel-boats farther up the river in one hour than thirty men and thirty mules can do it in two , it is believed that the old-fashioned towing industry is on its death-bed .
Parsing [sent. 1306 len. 19]: A second steamboat began work in the Neckar three months after the first one was put in service .
Parsing [sent. 1307 len. 47]: -LSB- Figure 4 -RSB- At noon we stepped ashore and bought some bottled beer and got some chickens cooked , while the raft waited ; then we immediately put to sea again , and had our dinner while the beer was cold and the chickens hot .
Parsing [sent. 1308 len. 40]: There is no pleasanter place for such a meal than a raft that is gliding down the winding Neckar past green meadows and wooded hills , and slumbering villages , and craggy heights graced with crumbling towers and battlements .
Parsing [sent. 1309 len. 14]: In one place we saw a nicely dressed German gentleman without any spectacles .
Parsing [sent. 1310 len. 11]: Before I could come to anchor he had got underway .
Parsing [sent. 1311 len. 6]: It was a great pity .
Parsing [sent. 1312 len. 10]: I so wanted to make a sketch of him .
Parsing [sent. 1313 len. 38]: The captain comforted me for my loss , however , by saying that the man was without any doubt a fraud who had spectacles , but kept them in his pocket in order to make himself conspicuous .
Parsing [sent. 1314 len. 13]: Below Hassmersheim we passed Hornberg , Goetz von Berlichingen 's old castle .
Parsing [sent. 1315 len. 33]: It stands on a bold elevation two hundred feet above the surface of the river ; it has high vine-clad walls enclosing trees , and a peaked tower about seventy-five feet high .
Parsing [sent. 1316 len. 25]: The steep hillside , from the castle clear down to the water 's edge , is terraced , and clothed thick with grape vines .
Parsing [sent. 1317 len. 8]: This is like farming a mansard roof .
Parsing [sent. 1318 len. 22]: All the steeps along that part of the river which furnish the proper exposure , are given up to the grape .
Parsing [sent. 1319 len. 10]: That region is a great producer of Rhine wines .
Parsing [sent. 1320 len. 26]: The Germans are exceedingly fond of Rhine wines ; they are put up in tall , slender bottles , and are considered a pleasant beverage .
Parsing [sent. 1321 len. 9]: One tells them from vinegar by the label .
Parsing [sent. 1322 len. 18]: The Hornberg hill is to be tunneled , and the new railway will pass under the castle .
Parsing [sent. 1323 len. 45]: THE CAVE OF THE SPECTER Two miles below Hornberg castle is a cave in a low cliff , which the captain of the raft said had once been occupied by a beautiful heiress of Hornberg -- the Lady Gertrude -- in the old times .
Parsing [sent. 1324 len. 7]: It was seven hundred years ago .
Parsing [sent. 1325 len. 20]: She had a number of rich and noble lovers and one poor and obscure one , Sir Wendel Lobenfeld .
Parsing [sent. 1326 len. 18]: With the native chuckleheadedness of the heroine of romance , she preferred the poor and obscure lover .
Parsing [sent. 1327 len. 62]: With the native sound judgment of the father of a heroine of romance , the von Berlichingen of that day shut his daughter up in his donjon keep , or his oubliette , or his culverin , or some such place , and resolved that she should stay there until she selected a husband from among her rich and noble lovers .
Parsing [sent. 1328 len. 34]: The latter visited her and persecuted her with their supplications , but without effect , for her heart was true to her poor despised Crusader , who was fighting in the Holy Land .
Parsing [sent. 1329 len. 39]: Finally , she resolved that she would endure the attentions of the rich lovers no longer ; so one stormy night she escaped and went down the river and hid herself in the cave on the other side .
Parsing [sent. 1330 len. 16]: Her father ransacked the country for her , but found not a trace of her .
Parsing [sent. 1331 len. 52]: As the days went by , and still no tidings of her came , his conscience began to torture him , and he caused proclamation to be made that if she were yet living and would return , he would oppose her no longer , she might marry whom she would .
Parsing [sent. 1332 len. 36]: The months dragged on , all hope forsook the old man , he ceased from his customary pursuits and pleasures , he devoted himself to pious works , and longed for the deliverance of death .
Parsing [sent. 1333 len. 38]: Now just at midnight , every night , the lost heiress stood in the mouth of her cave , arrayed in white robes , and sang a little love ballad which her Crusader had made for her .
Parsing [sent. 1334 len. 61]: She judged that if he came home alive the superstitious peasants would tell him about the ghost that sang in the cave , and that as soon as they described the ballad he would know that none but he and she knew that song , therefore he would suspect that she was alive , and would come and find her .
Parsing [sent. 1335 len. 21]: As time went on , the people of the region became sorely distressed about the Specter of the Haunted Cave .
Parsing [sent. 1336 len. 24]: It was said that ill luck of one kind or another always overtook any one who had the misfortune to hear that song .
Parsing [sent. 1337 len. 16]: Eventually , every calamity that happened thereabouts was laid at the door of that music .
Parsing [sent. 1338 len. 24]: Consequently , no boatmen would consent to pass the cave at night ; the peasants shunned the place , even in the daytime .
Parsing [sent. 1339 len. 26]: But the faithful girl sang on , night after night , month after month , and patiently waited ; her reward must come at last .
Parsing [sent. 1340 len. 41]: Five years dragged by , and still , every night at midnight , the plaintive tones floated out over the silent land , while the distant boatmen and peasants thrust their fingers into their ears and shuddered out a prayer .
Parsing [sent. 1341 len. 27]: And now came the Crusader home , bronzed and battle-scarred , but bringing a great and splendid fame to lay at the feet of his bride .
Parsing [sent. 1342 len. 51]: The old lord of Hornberg received him as his son , and wanted him to stay by him and be the comfort and blessing of his age ; but the tale of that young girl 's devotion to him and its pathetic consequences made a changed man of the knight .
Parsing [sent. 1343 len. 8]: He could not enjoy his well-earned rest .
Parsing [sent. 1344 len. 52]: He said his heart was broken , he would give the remnant of his life to high deeds in the cause of humanity , and so find a worthy death and a blessed reunion with the brave true heart whose love had more honored him than all his victories in war .

Parsing [sent. 1747 len. 17]: CHAPTER XIX -LSB- The Deadly Jest of Dilsberg -RSB- However , I wander from the raft .
Parsing [sent. 1748 len. 54]: We made the port of Necharsteinach in good season , and went to the hotel and ordered a trout dinner , the same to be ready against our return from a two-hour pedestrian excursion to the village and castle of Dilsberg , a mile distant , on the other side of the river .
Parsing [sent. 1749 len. 29]: I do not mean that we proposed to be two hours making two miles -- no , we meant to employ most of the time in inspecting Dilsberg .
Parsing [sent. 1750 len. 7]: For Dilsberg is a quaint place .
Parsing [sent. 1751 len. 10]: It is most quaintly and picturesquely situated , too .
Parsing [sent. 1752 len. 167]: Imagine the beautiful river before you ; then a few rods of brilliant green sward on its opposite shore ; then a sudden hill -- no preparatory gently rising slopes , but a sort of instantaneous hill -- a hill two hundred and fifty or three hundred feet high , as round as a bowl , with the same taper upward that an inverted bowl has , and with about the same relation of height to diameter that distinguishes a bowl of good honest depth -- a hill which is thickly clothed with green bushes -- a comely , shapely hill , rising abruptly out of the dead level of the surrounding green plains , visible from a great distance down the bends of the river , and with just exactly room on the top of its head for its steepled and turreted and roof-clustered cap of architecture , which same is tightly jammed and compacted within the perfectly round hoop of the ancient village wall .
Parsing [sent. 1753 len. 37]: There is no house outside the wall on the whole hill , or any vestige of a former house ; all the houses are inside the wall , but there is n't room for another one .
Parsing [sent. 1754 len. 16]: It is really a finished town , and has been finished a very long time .
Parsing [sent. 1755 len. 47]: There is no space between the wall and the first circle of buildings ; no , the village wall is itself the rear wall of the first circle of buildings , and the roofs jut a little over the wall and thus furnish it with eaves .
Parsing [sent. 1756 len. 50]: The general level of the massed roofs is gracefully broken and relieved by the dominating towers of the ruined castle and the tall spires of a couple of churches ; so , from a distance Dilsberg has rather more the look of a king 's crown than a cap .
Parsing [sent. 1757 len. 27]: That lofty green eminence and its quaint coronet form quite a striking picture , you may be sure , in the flush of the evening sun .

Parsing [sent. 1762 len. 12]: This path had been traveled by many generations of these people .
Parsing [sent. 1763 len. 33]: They have always gone down to the valley to earn their bread , but they have always climbed their hill again to eat it , and to sleep in their snug town .
Parsing [sent. 1764 len. 36]: It is said that the Dilsbergers do not emigrate much ; they find that living up there above the world , in their peaceful nest , is pleasanter than living down in the troublous world .
Parsing [sent. 1765 len. 52]: The seven hundred inhabitants are all blood-kin to each other , too ; they have always been blood-kin to each other for fifteen hundred years ; they are simply one large family , and they like the home folks better than they like strangers , hence they persistently stay at home .

Parsing [sent. 1781 len. 23]: They said that in the old day its bottom was below the level of the Neckar , hence the water-supply was inexhaustible .
Parsing [sent. 1782 len. 71]: But there were some who believed it had never been a well at all , and was never deeper than it is now -- eighty feet ; that at that depth a subterranean passage branched from it and descended gradually to a remote place in the valley , where it opened into somebody 's cellar or other hidden recess , and that the secret of this locality is now lost .

Parsing [sent. 2491 len. 22]: We rest on Sunday , because the commandment requires it ; the Germans rest on Sunday because the commandment requires it .
Parsing [sent. 2492 len. 15]: But in the definition of the word `` rest '' lies all the difference .
Parsing [sent. 2493 len. 62]: With us , its Sunday meaning is , stay in the house and keep still ; with the Germans its Sunday and week-day meanings seem to be the same -- rest the TIRED PART , and never mind the other parts of the frame ; rest the tired part , and use the means best calculated to rest that particular part .
Parsing [sent. 2494 len. 170]: Thus : If one 's duties have kept him in the house all the week , it will rest him to be out on Sunday ; if his duties have required him to read weighty and serious matter all the week , it will rest him to read light matter on Sunday ; if his occupation has busied him with death and funerals all the week , it will rest him to go to the theater Sunday night and put in two or three hours laughing at a comedy ; if he is tired with digging ditches or felling trees all the week , it will rest him to lie quiet in the house on Sunday ; if the hand , the arm , the brain , the tongue , or any other member , is fatigued with inanition , it is not to be rested by addeding a day 's inanition ; but if a member is fatigued with exertion , inanition is the right rest for it .
Parsing [sent. 2495 len. 35]: Such is the way in which the Germans seem to define the word `` rest '' ; that is to say , they rest a member by recreating , recuperating , restoring its forces .
Parsing [sent. 2496 len. 7]: But our definition is less broad .
Parsing [sent. 2497 len. 29]: We all rest alike on Sunday -- by secluding ourselves and keeping still , whether that is the surest way to rest the most of us or not .

Parsing [sent. 2532 len. 145]: A beautiful air ran through the music , without ceasing , sometimes loud and strong , sometimes so soft that it could hardly be distinguished -- but it was always there ; it swung grandly along through the shrill whistling of the storm-wind , the rattling patter of the rain , and the boom and crash of the thunder ; it wound soft and low through the lesser sounds , the distant ones , such as the throbbing of the convent bell , the melodious winding of the hunter 's horn , the distressed bayings of his dogs , and the solemn chanting of the monks ; it rose again , with a jubilant ring , and mingled itself with the country songs and dances of the peasants assembled in the convent hall to cheer up the rescued huntsman while he ate his supper .
Parsing [sent. 2533 len. 11]: The instruments imitated all these sounds with a marvelous exactness .
Parsing [sent. 2534 len. 67]: More than one man started to raise his umbrella when the storm burst forth and the sheets of mimic rain came driving by ; it was hardly possible to keep from putting your hand to your hat when the fierce wind began to rage and shriek ; and it was NOT possible to refrain from starting when those sudden and charmingly real thunder-crashes were let loose .

Parsing [sent. 2574 len. 28]: CHAPTER XXV -LSB- Hunted by the Little Chamois -RSB- Next morning we left in the train for Switzerland , and reached Lucerne about ten o'clock at night .
Parsing [sent. 2575 len. 17]: The first discovery I made was that the beauty of the lake had not been exaggerated .
Parsing [sent. 2576 len. 10]: Within a day or two I made another discovery .
Parsing [sent. 2577 len. 45]: This was , that the lauded chamois is not a wild goat ; that it is not a horned animal ; that it is not shy ; that it does not avoid human society ; and that there is no peril in hunting it .
Parsing [sent. 2578 len. 127]: The chamois is a black or brown creature no bigger than a mustard seed ; you do not have to go after it , it comes after you ; it arrives in vast herds and skips and scampers all over your body , inside your clothes ; thus it is not shy , but extremely sociable ; it is not afraid of man , on the contrary , it will attack him ; its bite is not dangerous , but neither is it pleasant ; its activity has not been overstated -- if you try to put your finger on it , it will skip a thousand times its own length at one jump , and no eye is sharp enough to see where it lights .
Parsing [sent. 2579 len. 61]: A great deal of romantic nonsense has been written about the Swiss chamois and the perils of hunting it , whereas the truth is that even women and children hunt it , and fearlessly ; indeed , everybody hunts it ; the hunting is going on all the time , day and night , in bed and out of it .
Parsing [sent. 2580 len. 33]: It is poetic foolishness to hunt it with a gun ; very few people do that ; there is not one man in a million who can hit it with a gun .
Parsing [sent. 2581 len. 23]: It is much easier to catch it than it is to shoot it , and only the experienced chamois-hunter can do either .
Parsing [sent. 2582 len. 16]: Another common piece of exaggeration is that about the `` scarcity '' of the chamois .
Parsing [sent. 2583 len. 7]: It is the reverse of scarce .
Parsing [sent. 2584 len. 14]: Droves of one hundred million chamois are not unusual in the Swiss hotels .
Parsing [sent. 2585 len. 13]: Indeed , they are so numerous as to be a great pest .
Parsing [sent. 2586 len. 32]: The romancers always dress up the chamois-hunter in a fanciful and picturesque costume , whereas the best way to hunt this game is to do it without any costume at all .
Parsing [sent. 2587 len. 21]: The article of commerce called chamois-skin is another fraud ; nobody could skin a chamois , it is too small .
Parsing [sent. 2588 len. 21]: The creature is a humbug in every way , and everything which has been written about it is sentimental exaggeration .
Parsing [sent. 2589 len. 54]: It was no pleasure to me to find the chamois out , for he had been one of my pet illusions ; all my life it had been my dream to see him in his native wilds some day , and engage in the adventurous sport of chasing him from cliff to cliff .
Parsing [sent. 2590 len. 78]: It is no pleasure to me to expose him , now , and destroy the reader 's delight in him and respect for him , but still it must be done , for when an honest writer discovers an imposition it is his simple duty to strip it bare and hurl it down from its place of honor , no matter who suffers by it ; any other course would render him unworthy of the public confidence .
Parsing [sent. 2591 len. 6]: Lucerne is a charming place .
Parsing [sent. 2592 len. 86]: It begins at the water 's edge , with a fringe of hotels , and scrambles up and spreads itself over two or three sharp hills in a crowded , disorderly , but picturesque way , offering to the eye a heaped-up confusion of red roofs , quaint gables , dormer windows , toothpick steeples , with here and there a bit of ancient embattled wall bending itself over the ridges , worm-fashion , and here and there an old square tower of heavy masonry .

Parsing [sent. 2594 len. 24]: Between the curving line of hotels and the lake is a broad avenue with lamps and a double rank of low shade trees .

Parsing [sent. 2598 len. 47]: The front rooms of the hotels have little railed balconies , where one may take his private luncheon in calm , cool comfort and look down upon this busy and pretty scene and enjoy it without having to do any of the work connected with it .
Parsing [sent. 2599 len. 19]: Most of the people , both male and female , are in walking costume , and carry alpenstocks .
Parsing [sent. 2600 len. 21]: Evidently , it is not considered safe to go about in Switzerland , even in town , without an alpenstock .
Parsing [sent. 2601 len. 27]: If the tourist forgets and comes down to breakfast without his alpenstock he goes back and gets it , and stands it up in the corner .
Parsing [sent. 2602 len. 47]: When his touring in Switzerland is finished , he does not throw that broomstick away , but lugs it home with him , to the far corners of the earth , although this costs him more trouble and bother than a baby or a courier could .
Parsing [sent. 2603 len. 49]: You see , the alpenstock is his trophy ; his name is burned upon it ; and if he has climbed a hill , or jumped a brook , or traversed a brickyard with it , he has the names of those places burned upon it , too .
Parsing [sent. 2604 len. 19]: Thus it is his regimental flag , so to speak , and bears the record of his achievements .

Parsing [sent. 4523 len. 16]: I read several books , and here are some of the things I found out .
Parsing [sent. 4524 len. 16]: One 's shoes must be strong and heavy , and have pointed hobnails in them .
Parsing [sent. 4525 len. 23]: The alpenstock must be of the best wood , for if it should break , loss of life might be the result .
Parsing [sent. 4526 len. 19]: One should carry an ax , to cut steps in the ice with , on the great heights .
Parsing [sent. 4527 len. 57]: There must be a ladder , for there are steep bits of rock which can be surmounted with this instrument -- or this utensil -- but could not be surmounted without it ; such an obstruction has compelled the tourist to waste hours hunting another route , when a ladder would have saved him all trouble .
Parsing [sent. 4528 len. 40]: One must have from one hundred and fifty to five hundred feet of strong rope , to be used in lowering the party down steep declivities which are too steep and smooth to be traversed in any other way .
Parsing [sent. 4529 len. 100]: One must have a steel hook , on another rope -- a very useful thing ; for when one is ascending and comes to a low bluff which is yet too high for the ladder , he swings this rope aloft like a lasso , the hook catches at the top of the bluff , and then the tourist climbs the rope , hand over hand -- being always particular to try and forget that if the hook gives way he will never stop falling till he arrives in some part of Switzerland where they are not expecting him .
Parsing [sent. 4530 len. 46]: Another important thing -- there must be a rope to tie the whole party together with , so that if one falls from a mountain or down a bottomless chasm in a glacier , the others may brace back on the rope and save him .
Parsing [sent. 4531 len. 34]: One must have a silk veil , to protect his face from snow , sleet , hail and gale , and colored goggles to protect his eyes from that dangerous enemy , snow-blindness .
Parsing [sent. 4532 len. 28]: Finally , there must be some porters , to carry provisions , wine and scientific instruments , and also blanket bags for the party to sleep in .
